caption: The image is a close-up dermoscopy of a foot, specifically showing the heel area. The region of interest, located left-center horizontally and lower-middle vertically, with an area ratio of 2.3%, exhibits a foot ulcer with irregular edges, a heterogeneous texture, and a noticeable disruption in skin integrity. This ulceration could be related to other regions of the foot, potentially indicating compromised blood flow or diabetic neuropathy, which are common underlying conditions for foot ulcers. The ulcer's presence suggests a need for careful monitoring and management to prevent further complications such as infection or amputation.

caption: The poster is discussing Pityriasis Rosea and seeking information about their treatment options. Pityriasis Rosea often presents without prominent mother patches on limbs. Treatment usually involves self-resolution within 6-8 weeks. Therapeutic options include UVB phototherapy every other day with progressively increasing dosages, oral administration of Compound Qingdai Pills, Histamine Blockers like Chlorpheniramine, Vitamin C, and Calcium Gluconate to alleviate allergic symptoms such as itching. Dietary restrictions on spicy foods and alcohol can significantly shorten the duration of the disease.
truncated_caption: The poster is discussing Pityriasis Rosea and seeking information about their treatment options. Pityriasis Rosea often presents without prominent mother patches on limbs. Treatment usually involves self-resolution within 6-8 weeks. Therapeutic options include UVB phototherapy every other day with progressively increasing dosages, oral administration of Compound Qingdai Pills, Histamine Blockers like Chlorpheniramine, Vitamin C, and Calcium Gluconate to alleviate allergic symptoms such as itching. Dietary restrictions on spicy foods and alcohol can significantly shorten the duration of the disease.

caption: The poster reported having a growth starting from the head and spreading to the temple area, first noticed around the age of 8 or 9 and has not spread for the last three decades, now in their thirties. The growth occasionally causes itching on the eyelid area. Medical consultations occurred about a decade ago leading to a diagnosis of flat warts by several doctors. Treatments with caustic lotion were attempted, which temporarily removed the warts, but they quickly regrew. The discussion in the forum led to a consensus among responders, who suggested that the condition described is likely verrucous nevus. No new symptoms or additional diagnostic insights were discussed beyond the initial description. No new treatments were suggested in the forum responses.

caption: This image discusses mucormycosis, a rapidly progressive fungal infection that can involve the skin, GI tract, lungs, and other organs. caption: An 8-year-old male patient is experiencing nail malnutrition (甲营养不良). Routine blood tests, trace elements, and fungal tests on nails have all returned normal results. There was a discussion among forum users about the diagnosis and treatment of the patient's condition. It was mentioned that nail malnutrition can be difficult to diagnose and treat, and suggested treatments were largely limited to supplementing trace elements. Different diagnoses such as nail eczema or lichen planus were considered, though the exact diagnosis remained unclear. There were mentions of conditions including nail thickening and irregularities accompanied by redness around the nails. A suggestion was made to conduct a pathological examination to better identify the condition, possibly leaning towards the diagnosis of nail lichen planus.

caption: An 80-year-old female presents with reddish, swollen, warm, and painful right lower leg persisting for 4 days. The symptoms started shortly after she scratched her leg due to 'athlete's foot' and rapidly progressed to involve the entire limb. She experienced fever with a highest recorded temperature of 38.1°C and has not received any treatment prior to hospital visit. During forum discussion, diagnosis of erysipelas, a type of lymphatic infection caused by a skin fungal infection from athlete's foot, was considered. The agreed treatment was bed rest, elevation of the affected limb, and administration of penicillin. Additionally, some suggestions included using traditional Chinese medicine formulations like Si Miao Yong An Tang featuring ingredients such as honeysuckle, scrophularia, licorice, and angelica.
truncated_caption: An 80-year-old female presents with reddish, swollen, warm, and painful right lower leg persisting for 4 days. The symptoms started shortly after she scratched her leg due to 'athlete's foot' and rapidly progressed to involve the entire limb. Additionally, some suggestions included using traditional Chinese medicine formulations like Si Miao Yong An Tang featuring ingredients such as honeysuckle, scrophularia, licorice, and angelica.

caption: A 63-year-old male complains of generalized itching, with hand backs and neck skin lesions that have persisted for more than ten years and lesions on the trunk and limbs' extensor surfaces for around six months. The primary condition discussed is Chronic Actinic Dermatitis (CAD). Other diagnoses considered are chronic eczema, generalized eczema, disseminated neurodermatitis, and the potential for Mycosis Fungoides (MF) being ruled out through pathology. Treatment suggestions include a regimen of Methimazole, Chlorpheniramine, Vitamin C, Compound Danshen Tablets, Vitamin B1, with specific dosages and treatment courses noted, including injections and topical applications. The possibility of chronic widespread neurodermatitis or chronic eczema along with treatments involving Methimazole, Chlorpheniramine, Vitamin C, Compound Danshen, and Vitamin B1 oral pills, and sulfur ointment applications for itching is also discussed.
truncated_caption: A 63-year-old male complains of generalized itching, with hand backs and neck skin lesions that have persisted for more than ten years and lesions on the trunk and limbs' extensor surfaces for around six months. The primary condition discussed is Chronic Actinic Dermatitis (CAD). Other diagnoses considered are chronic eczema, generalized eczema, disseminated neurodermatitis, and the potential for Mycosis Fungoides (MF) being ruled out through pathology. Treatment suggestions include a regimen of Methimazole, Chlorpheniramine, Vitamin C, Compound Danshen Tablets, Vitamin B1, with specific dosages and treatment courses noted, including injections and topical applications. The possibility of chronic widespread neurodermatitis or chronic eczema along with treatments involving Methimazole, Chlorpheniramine, Vitamin C, Compound Danshen, and Vitamin B1 oral pills, and sulfur ointment applications for itching is also discussed.
hierarchical_disease_label: inflammatory, non-infectious, chronic actinic dermatitis, dermatitis

caption: This image shows a dermatologist discussing various skin conditions with a patient. The patient has a skin disease that appears as large, white, cicatricial patches on the skin, mainly located on the nose. The dermatologist considers various options for the diagnosis, including actinic keratosis, lichen sclerosus, granulomatous inflammation, sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, lymphoma, and demodex. The dermatologist also mentions that the patient has good health and there are no comedonal eye openings, which is a clue that it may not be lichen sclerosus. The treatment options for this skin disease include topical treatments and, in some cases, surgery.

caption: This image describes the clinical presentation of MF in children, which can be misleading and cause delays in diagnosis. It presents as patches and plaque on unexposed areas such as the breast, lower abdomen, and buttocks, but in 45% of cases, it appears as whitish, hypopigmented lesions.
